Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 43459  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
September 2010 
 
 
 
India: Capacity Development for Project 
Implementation 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
as of 31 August 2010 
 
Currency Unit –  Re/Rs 
Re1.00 =  $0.02 
$1.00 =  Rs46.00 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CEAI  –  Consulting Engineers Association of India 
  DEA  –  Department of Economic Affairs 
  EA  –  executing agency 
  FIDIC  –  Fédération Internationale des Ingénieurs-Conseils (Federation 
of International Consulting Engineers) 
  MDB  –  multilateral development bank 
  TA   –  technical assistance 
  TPRM  –  tripartite portfolio review meetings 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention  
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (agricultural production and markets; irrigation, 
drainage, and flood protection; agriculture and rural sector 
development; conventional energy, electricity transmission and 
distribution; energy utility services; energy sector development; 
investment funds; small and medium-sized enterprise finance and 
leasing; water supply and sanitation; waste management; slum 
upgrading and housing; urban sector development; public 
expenditure and fiscal management; public administration; rail 
transport; road transport; urban transport) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity development (institutional development, organizational 
development); economic growth (knowledge, science, and 
technological capacities); environmental sustainability 
(environmental policy and legislation); governance (public 
administration [national, decentralized, and regional], anticorruption)
Location impact  –  National (high), urban (medium), rural (medium) 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director-General  S. H. Rahman, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Country Director  H. Kim, India Resident Mission, SARD 
Team leader  A. Vikram Harsha, Portfolio Management Officer, SARD 
Team members  L. Boenawan Sondjaja, Head, Portfolio Management Unit , SARD 
  P. Sahu, Project Analyst, SARD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since starting its operations in India in 1986, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has 
approved 115 projects for $24 billion. These totals include regular project and program loans 
and multitranche financing facilities (whose amounts have been calculated on a full-facility 
basis). Initially, most loans were to finance national projects, but since 1998 more ADB loans 
have financed state projects. ADB’s active portfolio in India as of 1 July 2010 consisted of 14 
loans each in energy and transport, 13 in urban development, 9 in finance and governance, and 
2 in agriculture. Almost half of the net loan amount was to state governments or state agencies, 
spread across 18 states. In recent years ADB operations have expanded rapidly to such states 
as  Chattisgarh,  Jharkhand,  Orissa,  Uttarakhand  and  the  north  eastern  states  (Meghalaya, 
Mizoram, Nagaland, Sikkim and Tripura). In 2010, Delhi, Goa, Haryana, Maharashtra, Punjab, 
and Uttar Pradesh are likely to join the India portfolio. Many of the executing agencies (EAs) 
involved in ADB projects have limited capacity to implement large development projects so ADB 
has been providing capacity development technical assistance (TA) to conduct training for EA 
staff and to mentor them.1 
 
2.  So far, the TA provided by ADB has addressed specific themes or project needs. A 
common capacity development action plan that cuts across projects and covers the entire 
project cycle is needed. The Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) of the Government of India 
and project EAs have asked ADB on various occasions, including during the tripartite portfolio 
review meetings (TPRM) to conduct capacity development programs to enhance EAs’ project 
implementation  and  management  capacity  and  to  improve  project  readiness  at  entry.  In 
response, a new TA was included in the ADB country operations business plan, 2010. Following 
a discussion with the DEA, a consensus was reached on the purpose, scope, implementation 
arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The design and 
monitoring framework for the TA is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The India Resident Mission has been conducting TPRMs since September 2005 to 
review project performance, identify common and specific problems in project implementation, 
formulate  time-bound  action  plans  to  address  those  problems,  and  reach  agreement  on 
                                                 
1 ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for Capacity Development to Enhance Project Readiness & Results 
Monitoring for Transport Projects, Manila, (TA 7252-IND), ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for, Capacity 
Development for Strengthening Environmental and Social Safeguard Requirements, Manila, (TA 7256-IND), ADB. 
2009. Technical Assistance to India for Capacity Development of Assam Power Sector Utilities, Manila, (TA 7378-
IND), 1ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for Karnataka State Highway Network Improvement Strategy, 
Manila, (TA 7324-IND), ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for, Supporting an Initiative for Mainstreaming 
PPP for Providing Urban Amenities, Manila, (TA 7342-IND), ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for 
Advanced Project Preparedness for Poverty Reduction Support to JNNURM, Manila, (TA 7392-IND), ADB. 2009. 
Technical Assistance to India for Small and Medium Enterprise Trade Finance Development Facility, Manila, (TA 
7358-IND), 1ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for Advanced Project Preparedness for Poverty Reduction 
and Capacity Development for Sustainable Coastal Protection, Manila, (TA 7410-IND), ADB. 2009. Technical 
Assistance to India for Multi State and Multi Sector Project Management Capacity Building, Manila, (TA 7413-IND), 
ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for Integrated Water Resources Management and Sustainable Water 
Service Delivery in Karnataka, Manila, (TA 7418-IND), ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for Sustaining the 
Government of India –ADB Initiative for Mainstreaming PPP, Manila, (TA 7463-IND), ADB. 2009. Technical 
Assistance to India for Addressing Social and Health Issues Associated with Road Improvement, Manila, (TA 
7476), ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India for Capacity Development of Bihar Power Sector Entities, Manila, 
(TA 7478-IND) and ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to India for Capacity Building for Government Agencies 
Supporting ADB Operations in India, Manila, (TA 7511-IND). 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 July 2010.

2
measures needed to improve portfolio performance. Important measures identified at TPRMs to 
improve  the  portfolio  performance  include  (i)  improving  awareness  of  ADB's  procedures 
governing  procurement,  consultant  selection,  disbursement,  and  safeguard  procedures;  
(ii)  increasing  the  participation  of  contractors  in  bidding  by  disseminating  procurement 
information through national and project-specific business opportunity seminars; (iii) improving 
contract  management  of  EAs  through  capacity  development  in  contract  administration;  
(iv)  streamlining  approvals  for  preconstruction  activities  and  environmental  clearances;  
(v)  identifying  opportunities  for  public–private  partnerships  under  ADB-financed  projects;  
(vi)  conducting  joint  field  visits;  (vii)  focusing  on  the  reform  agenda  and  sustainability,  
(viii)  improving  project  readiness  at  entry  through  a  checklist;  and  (ix)  disseminating  best 
practices and innovations in project implementation. 
 
4.  Since 2008, DEA, EAs and ADB have placed greater emphasis on achieving outputs 
and outcomes and in making progress with the reform agenda at the TPRM, in addition to 
reviewing the achievements of contract awards and disbursement against targets. This change 
in emphasis requires capacity development in areas that are central to achieving sector reforms. 
 
5.  The India Resident Mission conducted a training needs assessment survey in June 2008 
among EAs of ongoing and future projects in consultation with the DEA. EAs identified a training 
requirement for 6,400 EA staff in ADB policies on safeguards, contract administration, project 
management, procurement, consultancy selection and disbursement, in addition to other topics 
such as detailed project report preparation, operation and maintenance, quality assurance, 
geographical  information  systems  and  mapping,  construction  technologies,  design  of  flood 
control  structures,  computer-aided  design  for  urban  projects,  tunneling  technologies, 
environmental management, community mobilization, and market research and surveying. A 
new training needs assessment survey has been initiated to assess the training needs of EA 
staff for 2010–2012. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact of the TA would be timely delivery of the project benefits. The outcome of 
the TA would be improved capacities of EA staff in implementing ADB-financed projects.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The TA is expected to deliver training programs to about 3,500 EA staff working on 
ongoing and future ADB-financed projects.  A training calendar for 2010–2013 will list all training 
topics pertaining to project implementation and thematic areas with tentative training dates. The 
training modules will be designed to improve awareness of existing government systems in 
addition to ADB procedures. The calendar will be disseminated to EAs and posted on the 
resident mission website to enable EAs to plan the participation of their staff in advance.  
 
8.  Project implementation training programs will cover ADB procedures on procurement, 
consultant  selection,  disbursement,  and  safeguard  procedures  in  addition  to  contract 
administration using the Federation of International Consulting Engineers (FIDIC) conditions of 
contract and project management. Staff from ADB’s Central Operations Services Office will 
conduct sessions during these programs to address procurement issues raised by EA staff. The 
training will consist of national and project-specific programs.  The project management module 
will include monitoring and evaluation techniques. About 24 national and 10 project-specific 
programs  on  project  implementation  will  be  provided  to  about  2,800  EA  staff.  Project 
implementation training programs will target middle and junior management.

3   
9.  Training in thematic topics will cover such topics as sector and institutional reform to 
improve sector performance, service delivery, and sustainability. Specific issues that have been 
identified  include  water  tariffs,  nonrevenue  water,  sewerage  charges,  power  sector  loss 
reductions,  carbon  credits,  road  safety,  sustainable  transport,  quality  control,  asset 
management, public–private partnership, and gender. About 14 programs will be provided to 
about 700 EA staff. Thematic training programs will target senior management. 
 
10.  Cross-learning will be promoted by encouraging EA staff to visit project sites of projects 
that are performing well to learn from their implementation experience. Best practices identified 
during project preparation and implementation will be disseminated among the EAs and other 
stakeholders.  
  
11.  National and project-specific business opportunity seminars will be conducted to improve 
the participation of contractors, consultants, and NGOs in ADB-funded projects. Information on 
procurement  and  consultancy  opportunities  under  national  and  ADB  procedures  will  be 
distributed.  
 
12.  The resident mission will deliver the training programs through national and international 
agencies, academic institutions, training center at the resident mission and through national 
consultants who will visit project offices. The national consultants will provide mentoring support 
to EAs as they prepare bid documents and evaluate bids. This mentoring support will be 
focused on new projects where the loan consultants have not been engaged. Where loan 
consultants have been fielded, the mentoring will not duplicate their inputs.   
 
13.  Participants  and  project  directors  will  be  able  to  register  for  courses  and  provide 
feedback via the resident mission website.  
 
14.  The resident mission will identify national academic institutions to conduct the training 
programs.  The  institutions  will  charge  the  EAs  fees  for  these  training  programs.  ADB,  in 
consultation with the DEA, will encourage EAs to pay a portion of these fees from the training 
allocations under  their  loans.  This  will  improve  the  long-term  sustainability  of  the  capacity 
building programs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is $2 million, of which $1.5 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
contribute $500,000 toward the travel costs, per diem, and salary of government agency staff 
participating  in  the  training  programs.  Expenditure  related  to  accommodation,  food  for  the 
participants,  training  venues,  travel  cost  of  ADB  resource  persons,  total  cost  of  non-ADB 
resource persons, and training materials will be paid from the TA. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The DEA, Ministry of Finance, Government of India will be the EA. The TA will be 
implemented  from  15  September  2010  to  30  September  2013.  One  individual  national 
consultant will be recruited for 24 person-months under the TA to conduct project-specific 
capacity development programs on ADB’s procurement and consultant selection procedures 
and to provide mentoring support to EAs as they prepare documentation. Individual international 
consultants will be recruited for 16 person-days and one national consultant will be recruited for 
8 person-days to conduct training programs on the FIDIC conditions of contract through the 
Consulting Engineers Association of India (CEAI). One individual national consultant will be 
recruited for 3 person-months intermittently to advice on structuring, delivery and evaluation of

4
capacity development programs under the TA. The consultants will be engaged in accordance 
with the ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB 
will also provide staff as resource persons, organize the training programs and provide training 
materials. The government will meet expenditure related to travel, per diem, and salary of EA 
staff participating in the training programs. 
 
17.  The resident mission will organize the training programs on ADB procedures with the 
help of resource persons from ADB and national consultants. The travel cost of ADB resource 
persons and the total cost of non-ADB resource persons will be met from TA funds. Training 
programs  on  thematic  topics  will be  conducted  with  the  help  of  national  and  international 
agencies or academic institutions with established expertise in these areas. The travel and 
related costs of resource persons for thematic topics will be met from TA funds. Programs on 
contract administration will be outsourced to CEAI using single-source selection as it is the only 
FIDIC member in India and is authorized to conduct FIDIC-accredited training seminars under 
an agreement between CEAI and FIDIC. A respected academic institution will be selected to 
design and deliver a project management program that is relevant to government agency staff.  
 
18.  The selection of EA staff for training programs will be done in consultation with the DEA.  
For project implementation training programs, preference will be given to middle and lower 
management as these categories have a lower attrition rate. This will ensure continuity of 
trained  staff  on  the  projects  during  implementation.  For  thematic  training  programs, 
preference will be given to senior management as the programs deal with policy issues. 
Staff from ongoing and future projects will attend the same sessions to encourage cross- 
learning. Detailed selection criteria will be developed during implementation in consultation 
with the DEA. 
 
19.  Under the TA, training material will be printed locally. This will reduce costs and simplify 
logistical arrangements (currently training materials are shipped from Manila).  
 
20.   An annual capacity development report will be prepared to document the improvement 
in the portfolio, the training programs conducted, feedback from participants, best practices, and 
sector  and  thematic  knowledge.  The  report  will  be  published  and  disseminated  to  all 
stakeholders.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION    
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Capacity Development for Project Implementation and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

7    Appendix 2 
 
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN

Appendix 3  8
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  In conducting the capacity development program, the capacity development technical 
assistance  (TA)  will  require  services  from  consulting  firms  and  individual  consultants  in 
specialized areas such as Federation of International Consulting Engineers (FIDIC) contract 
administration and ADB procurement procedures. 
 
A.  Contract Administration Training Program (FIDIC Conditions of Contract) 
 
2.  A consulting firm will be engaged to conduct two capacity development programs on 
contract administration for EA staff implementing ADB-funded projects in India. The consulting 
firm will be required to engage one FIDIC-accredited tutor from an ADB member country for 16 
person-days  and  one  national  consultant  for  8  person-days.  The  Consulting  Engineers 
Association of India (CEAI) will be engaged on single source selection procedures. 
 
3.  The objective of the program is to introduce government agency staff implementing 
ADB-funded projects in India to FIDIC conditions of contract with a special emphasis on the 
harmonized version of FIDIC conditions of contract developed for multilateral development 
banks (MDBs) and India case studies.  
 
4.  The consulting firm (CEAI) will provide the following services during the programs: 
 
(i)  engage  a  minimum  of  one  resource  person  from  FIDIC  to  introduce  the 
participants  to  FIDIC  conditions  of  contract  with  a  special  emphasis  on  the 
harmonized version of FIDIC conditions of contract developed for MDBs (the 
resource person from FIDIC should be available full-time during the course); 
(ii)  engage  a  minimum  of  one  resource  speaker  from  India  with  experience  in 
implementing  public  sector  projects  to  provide  India-specific  case  studies 
covering such issues as variations in bill of quantities items, liquidated damages, 
and time extension;  
(iii)  provide training materials, including hard copies of case studies discussed during 
the program and copies of presentations by resource speakers;  
(iv)  collect feedback from the participants and keep an attendance record in the form 
prescribed by ADB and submit them to ADB. 
 
5.  The program will be conducted in two modules of 3 days each per year.  
 
6.  The consulting firm will prepare a 3–4 page report containing feedback from participants,  
its findings, and suggestions for further improving the program. It will submit the report to ADB 
within 15 days of the conclusion of the program. 
 
B.  Training Program on ADB's Procurement and Consultant Selection Procedures 
 
7.  One individual national consultant will be engaged to conduct capacity development 
programs on ADB’s procurement and consultant selection procedures for government staff 
implementing ADB-funded projects in India and to give mentoring support to EAs in preparing 
the  necessary  documentation  at  the  project  office.  The  consultant will  be  engaged  for  24 
person-months. 
 
8.  In close consultation with ADB, the consultant will provide the following services:

9    Appendix 3 
 
(i)  design the course content for a training program on ADB’s procurement and 
consultant selection procedures at project sites as decided by ADB; 
(ii)  develop India-specific case studies for use during the training program; 
(iii)  provide on-the-job training to EA staff on preparing such documents as standard 
bidding documents and bid evaluation reports;  
(iv)  prepare training materials; and  
(v)  collect feedback from the participants and keep an attendance record in the form 
prescribed by ADB and submit them to ADB. 
 
9.  The consultant will submit an inception report, a report at the end of each training 
program, and a final report containing feedback from participants, findings, and suggestions for 
further improving the program. 
 
C.  Capacity Development Consultant 
 
10.  One individual national consultant will be recruited as a capacity development specialist. 
 
11.  In  close  consultation  with  ADB,  the  consultant  will  provide  advice  on  the  following 
services:  
 
(i)  effective structuring of capacity development programs; 
(ii)  various  options  available  for  effective  delivery  of  training  programs  including 
preferred methods of instruction; 
(iii)  effective evaluation techniques. 
 
12.      The consultancy will be for a period of 3 person-months intermittently. 
 
13.      The consultant will submit a report at the end of each assignment and a final report after 
conclusion of the consultancy containing feedback from participants, findings, and suggestions 
for further improving the program.
